results.title: Eyes and their care
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: The structure, functioning, physiology and hygiene of the eyes are studied, the following in detail: learning how to judge distance; eye movements; light receptors; field of vision; night blindness; double vision; near and far sightedness; infections of and protection for the eyes.

results.title: The Eyes and seeing
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 4. Physiology”.
Studies the eye, its component structures and their functions. Close-up studies of the parts of the eye and experiments with animals in a visual perception laboratory provide a clear distinction between the physical process and the electro-chemical process of seeing. Considers how light sources are focused on the retina activating light sensitive cells. Examines problems in determining how the brain evaluates and acts on visual stimuli.

results.title: Eye Witness. No. 93
results.creator_credit: Hector Lemieux, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is an inside story of the trucking business from the point of view of a driver of one of the huge long-distance trailer transports. He describes his customary 388-mile run between Montreal and New York and, in the process, shows what a highly organized operation trucking has become.

results.title: Patterns of heredity
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Eye on Research”.
What happens to human cells in certain cases of blood cancer? Can mongolism be inherited? What makes us grow old? In this study of the research being made into heredity, questions such as these are considered.

results.title: The Eye of the beholder
results.brief_description: Illustrates the idea that people often see what they want to see, what they are prepared to see and not what actually exists. A series of incidents involving an artist who appears to be involved in the murder of a woman are presented. These show how he appears to his mother, to a waiter, a cab driver, his landlord and a cleaning lady. The story, as seen through the eyes of these beholders is quite different from what we see when the entire incident is repeated as it actually happened. The films emphasises the importance of caution in judging people and that no two people see the same thing the same way.

results.title: The Eye hears the ear sees
results.creator_credit: Gavin Millar, Margaret Dale, British Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Shakespeare said it first, but here Gavin Millar of the BBC employs the phrase as a tribute to the unique filmmaking career of Norman McLaren. Millar talks with McLaren and another National Film Board film animator, Grant Munro, and shows many examples of the development of the McLaren style. It shows examples of his multiple exposure effects. Demonstrates how he makes moving pictures without cameras and sound tracks without instruments. Includes excerpts from his films, Hen hop, Pas de deux, etc. Photography by Robert Humble. (Awards: New York; Montevideo; Philadelphia.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gavin Millar, Margaret Dale, British Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: An Eye for business
results.brief_description: Shows how ideas and design are converted into computer language and how the “light pen” has enabled the engineer or designer to communicate with a computer in his own terms-pictorially-by the technique of computer graphics.

results.title: External respiration
results.brief_description: Illustrates and discusses, by means of animated diagrams, the passage of air from the nose to lungs, the function of the nasal passages, trachea, thorax, diaphragm and lungs, transference of oxygen to the bloodstream and the expulsion of surplus carbon-dioxide during expiration.

results.title: Exterior wall with tyrolean finish
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plastering”.
This first coat consists of a water repellent cement. Materials and their proportions are stated. The surface is scratched to provide a key for the next coat. This second coat is applied with the help of dots and screeds to ensure a true vertical surface. The formation of a plinth is demonstrated. This is made in two stages, core and finishing coat. The wall itself may be finished in various ways. Three different kinds of finishing coats are shows: Tyrolean finish, pebble dash, and rough cast.
